definitions.definition: to try to prevent something or to prevent somebody from doing something, especially by making it difficult to do or by showing that you do not approve of it
definitions.sensetop: discourage (doing) somethingdiscourage somebodydiscourage somebody from doing something

examples.text: a campaign to discourage investing in fossil fuel development
I leave a light on when I'm out to discourage burglars.
His parents tried to discourage him from being an actor.
Travel to the region is actively discouraged.
We tried to discourage him from resigning.

definitions.definition: to make somebody feel less confident or enthusiastic about doing something
definitions.sensetop: discourage somebody/somethingdiscourage somebody from doing something

examples.text: Don't be discouraged by the first failure—try again!
The weather discouraged people from attending.
From boyhood he had been easily discouraged by obstacles in his path.
High interest rates will discourage investment.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French descouragier, from des- (expressing reversal) + corage ‘courage’.
